moves.1. e4 c5: I have started using c5 recently and found it to be a very good reply from black.
moves.2. Qf3 Nc6: At this stage white has developed the queen early while black is developing its knight.
moves.3. c3 Nf6 4. Bc4: The development of the major pieces continue. There is hardly any movement of pawns.
moves.4... Ne5: Attacking move from black. The knight forks the queen and the bishop. I was expecting Qe2 as the reply from white.
moves.5... d5: More attack in the form of another fork -- this time forking the pawn and the bishop.
moves.6. Bxd5: This seems to be a logical reply from white. Another move that could be evaluated would be bb5+ which might even have been better.
moves.6... Nxd5 7. exd5 Qxd5: Now black has developed a potent attack.
moves.8. Nf3: White is threatening to drive the knight at e5 away.
moves.8... Nd3+: Nd3+ ! ... This might be the best move of the game from black. Instead of moving away the Knight take a threatening square
moves.10. Ne1: White tries to drive away the knight again. I did not want to move the knight away and wanted to keep pressure using major pieces. The next logical move was ...
moves.11. f3: White is in a cramped position with all its major pieces stuck away. Black has all the initiative.
moves.11... e6 12. b4:
White tries to free its King side pieces . This move looks very dubious to me as the e.p pawn capture would be protected by the queen. 

To add to this -- the White king is open to checks.
moves.12... cxb3 e.p. 13. a4 b2: The pawn is now threatening to take at least one major piece !
moves.14. Bxb2: I was thinking of taking the Bishop with my knight with Nb2+. But then on second thoughts I realized that re-inforcing the threat with the white queen could be even more dangerous for white !
moves.14... Qb3+ 15. Nc2 Qxb2: White has very limited options now.
moves.16. Qxd3: That is a blunder ! -- white misses the Bishop at f5.
moves.16... Bxd3 17. Nba3 Bxa3: The game is pretty much over here -- the next moves are pretty much forces upto the checkmate.
